segment.source: Terminology
segment.target: Terminology

segment.source: Deepest runtime idle platform state (DRIPS): The system is said to be in DRIPS when the system is consuming the lowest amount of power possible, limited by the system’s power floor.
segment.target: Deepest runtime idle platform state (DRIPS): The system is said to be in DRIPS when the system is consuming the lowest amount of power possible, limited by the system’s power floor.

segment.source: When the screen is turned off, the Modern Standby session starts and the system goes through multiple phases to move into a low-power state.
segment.target: When the screen is turned off, the Modern Standby session starts and the system goes through multiple phases to move into a low-power state.

segment.source: When the system is in the lowest-power state, the system is in DRIPS.
segment.target: When the system is in the lowest-power state, the system is in DRIPS.

segment.source: The system is not in DRIPS when it is performing tasks like receiving emails, updating live tiles with fresh content, receiving VoIP calls, or any other background task that requires system resources.
segment.target: The system is not in DRIPS when it is performing tasks like receiving emails, updating live tiles with fresh content, receiving VoIP calls, or any other background task that requires system resources.

segment.source: The more time the system spends in DRIPS before the screen is turned back on, the longer the battery life.
segment.target: The more time the system spends in DRIPS before the screen is turned back on, the longer the battery life.

segment.source: Activators: Software components that are allowed to perform work in the background while in Modern Standby.
segment.target: Activators: Software components that are allowed to perform work in the background while in Modern Standby.

segment.source: Tools
segment.target: Tools

segment.source: The Windows Performance Toolkit consists of two independent tools: Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) and Windows Performance Analyzer (WPA).
segment.target: The Windows Performance Toolkit consists of two independent tools: Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) and Windows Performance Analyzer (WPA).

segment.source: WPR is a powerful recording tool that creates Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) recordings.
segment.target: WPR is a powerful recording tool that creates Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) recordings.

segment.source: You can run WPR from the user interface (UI) or from the command line (CL).
segment.target: You can run WPR from the user interface (UI) or from the command line (CL).

segment.source: WPR provides built-in profiles that you can use to select the events you want to record.
segment.target: WPR provides built-in profiles that you can use to select the events you want to record.

segment.source: WPA is a powerful analysis tool that combines a flexible UI with extensive graphing capabilities and data tables that can be pivoted and have full text search capabilities.
segment.target: WPA is a powerful analysis tool that combines a flexible UI with extensive graphing capabilities and data tables that can be pivoted and have full text search capabilities.

segment.source: SleepStudy is a Windows diagnostics tool that supports Modern Standby (connected or disconnected).
segment.target: SleepStudy is a Windows diagnostics tool that supports Modern Standby (connected or disconnected).

segment.source: It monitors a Modern Standby PC’s behavior and provides actionable diagnostics on Modern Standby battery life.
segment.target: It monitors a Modern Standby PC’s behavior and provides actionable diagnostics on Modern Standby battery life.

segment.source: It’s available only on Modern Standby capable PCs.
segment.target: It’s available only on Modern Standby capable PCs.

segment.source: SleepStudy generates a summary of top issues that cause poor Modern Standby battery life.
segment.target: SleepStudy generates a summary of top issues that cause poor Modern Standby battery life.
